United Airlines flight 173 is arguably the most important crash in aviation
history if you ever took a flight after 1985 then I guarantee you that your
flight your safety has been impacted by this flight and in the final report investigators
list a probable cause for this crash as well as a contributing factor
the cause was the captain's failure to properly monitor the aircraft's fuel
State and to respond to both the low fuel State and the crew members
advisories regarding the fuel state the fact that contributing to the
accident was the failure of BB and frosty to either fully comprehend the
criticality of the fuel state or to successfully communicate their concern
to the captain the most alarming part of these findings
was that they were not isolated they were only the latest in a string of air crashes with similar causes in the 60s
and 70s the number of flights were growing dramatically as were the number of crashes
for example the most famous crash before flight 173 was probably the Tenerife
airport disaster in 1977. in this crash two fully laden 747s collided on the
runway killing 583 passengers and crew
similar to flight 173 the probable cause in this crash was a breakdown in
communication only this time it was both inside and outside of the two cockpits
Air Traffic Control also played a role so in this broader context the
recommendations from flight 173 were timely NASA had already identified the
issue of human error in the cockpit and were working on a solution called crew
resource management or CRM yeah I know hearing that acronym might make you
shudder a bit if you've ever worked on customer relationship management system but for today it means crew resource
management and in the investigation report of flight 173 Airlines were told to give
this training to their pilots typically the crew Resource Management
training should have two themes participative management for captains in
other words providing a non-threatening environment that actively encourages collaboration
and secondly assertiveness training for other cockpit crew members so this is how to get your
point across effectively in a non-threatening manner and while it originally started in the
cockpit these days cabin crew and ground crew are expected to have the training basically any and team involved with the
safe operation of the aircraft get the training now in modern organizational terms you
could summarize crew Resource Management as ensuring psychological safety in the cockpit the cabin the ground now I find
this really interesting as this recommendation actually predates the term psychological safety by about 20
years and what's also really interesting is the emphasis on the assertiveness of the
co-pilots so it's not just the responsibility of the captain to provide
a safe space it's the other crew members also taking responsibility for how their
message or advice is received and in the decades that have followed
the implementation of CRM starting with United Airlines in FL in 1981 makes
sense they'd be first indeed the culture of aviators has changed markedly it's no
longer a case of Captain knows best every young pilot knows no matter their
experience level that they not only have the right they have the responsibility
to speak up when something is not right
now you could argue in software the stakes aren't as high as human lives
but what if your failure to speak up Sparks a chain of events that results in
a data breach or loss of Faith with a major customer or potentially worse loss
of faith in yourself and of course being prepared to speak up
is different from knowing when to speak up how can you better tell if things are
wrong or require further examination that decisions are being made that ignore key evidence
we already got some tips from Finn and the team in Norway but what about Captain McBroom
Captain McBroom can teach us a lot about situational awareness this is a fundamental concept for aviators put
simply situational awareness is knowing what's going on around you
in the case study we saw Captain McBroom getting increasingly fixated on the
landing gear issue which left him unable to process the criticality of the fuel
situation he had lost his situational awareness
and if you are the proud owner of a human brain it's very easy to lose your
situational awareness much easier than we would like to admit
for example have you ever dived into an issue so deep and caught in the
technical wonder that you lost sight of what the problem was in the first place or were you so focused on getting to the
conference on time that you can't really recall a lot of your journey as an engineer if you fail to maintain
awareness of your situation you end up with a perfectly engineered feature that
nobody wants or a hot fix for a small ordering issue that leaves your app unable to process payments
so how can we maintain situational awareness in our roles as software
